trial_identification.studytitle: A novel cell therapy to treat patients with hepatitis C virus (HCV)infection.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Safety and efficacy of cell immunotherapy to treat hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon
Normal development and function of the immune system

interventions.interventions: Cell immunotherapy to elicit HCV-specific immune responses in patients who have previously failed interferon-based therapy. The dose will vary from 10,000 to 100 million HCV antigen positive cells, administered by the intradermal route. Patients will receive these cell numbers in 1, 2 or 3 doses with one week between doses.
interventions.comparator: Patients will represent their own control as the viral load and immunological parameters will be studied before and after intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Safety. Clinical examination. Haematology-full blood examination Clinical chemistry-full study, including liver function tests (LFT). HCV viral load.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Weekly during intervention and weekly for 6 weeks after intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Induction of HCV-specific cell mediated immunity. This will be assessed by Enzyme-linked immunosorbent spot (ELIspot) examination of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) using HCV peptide pools as the stimulating antigen. The viral load will be assessed by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Weekly during intervention and weekly for 6 weeks after intervention.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: HCV ribonuclei acid (RNA) positive for >6 months. Previously failed interferon-based therapy Infected with genotype 1 virus.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Hepatitis B virus (HBV)-positive Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive Evidence of autoimmunity

trial_design.concealment: The patients will be enrolled by a clinician who normally provides care. The trial will be discussed during a normal appointment in the liver clinic, the patient provided with a patient information and consent form (PICF) which he/she is encouraged to read and discuss with family/friends and/or their general practitioner. The consent form will be signed in the clinic in the presence of their liver specialist.
trial_design.sequence: Patients will be enrolled essentially as they appear in the clinic.
trial_design.designfeatures: The trial will be a dose escalation trial.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study is designed to examine the hypothesis that increasing the level of specific immunity to the proteins of hepatitis C virus will result in a reduction in the viral load and/or clearance of the virus.
